metadata.case_name: Hukumchand Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Central Bombay

facts.text: Hukumchand Mills Ltd. (assessee) is a public company incorporated in previous Indore State, owns a textile mill there.
Up to assessment year 1949-50, assessee assessed in British India as non-resident except 1948-49 as resident, on income falling within s.4(1)(a) or 4(1)(c) read with s.42 of Income Tax Act, 1922.
After Constitution, Indore became Part B State, Act brought into force from April 1, 1950; assessee liable as resident from 1950-51.
Dispute on proper written down value of buildings, machinery etc. for depreciation u/s 10(2)(vi).
Assessee contended u/s 10(5)(b): original cost as basis since no depreciation actually allowed under the Act.
Department: Depreciation allowed to arrive at total income as non-resident must be taken into account u/s 10(5)(b).
Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected assessee's contention.
Tribunal order dated October 8, 1958: Only depreciation entering computation of taxable income under Act is 'actually allowed', not total depreciation for total income.
Department urged before Tribunal: Apply para 2 of Taxation Laws (Part B States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950; deduct depreciation allowed under Industrial Tax Rules (Indore).
Tribunal permitted Department's contention, remanded to ITO to ascertain if depreciation allowed under Industrial Tax Rules and if rules relate to income-tax/super-tax/tax on profits of business.

Tribunal Reference u/s 66(1) on January 2, 1959: (1) Whether 'all depreciation actually allowed' in s.10(5)(b) refers only to depreciation for Indian income-tax; (2) Whether para 2 of Taxation Laws Order applies.
Bombay High Court judgment dated June 22, 1962: Q1 in favour of assessee; Q2: Para 2 valid but applies only if ITO decides factual questions in favour of Department.
High Court granted certificates u/s 66A to both assessee and CIT.
Civil Appeals 411-413 by assessee; 414-415 by CIT.

legal_issues.text: Whether Tribunal competent to entertain Department's contention on para 2 of Taxation Laws Order for first time and remand to ITO.
Whether 'all depreciation actually allowed' in s.10(5)(b) refers only to depreciation allowed for determining Indian income-tax liability.
Whether provisions of para 2 of Taxation Laws (Part B States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 apply to the case.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal not competent to go into applicability of para 2 of Taxation Laws Order; respondent should not have been allowed to raise it for first time before Tribunal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.33(4) Income Tax Act, 1922; Rule 12, 27, 28 Appellate Tribunal Rules, 1946

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal ought not to have remanded case to ITO for ascertaining depreciation under Industrial Tax Rules.

respondent_arguments.text: Provisions of para 2 of Taxation Laws Order applicable; depreciation under Industrial Tax Rules (Indore) to be deducted for written down value.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Para 2 Taxation Laws (Part B States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950

court_reasoning.text: No objection raised before Tribunal or High Court to Department raising para 2; even if implicit, Tribunal had jurisdiction u/s 33(4) to permit it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal powers under s.33(4) widest possible; 'pass such orders thereon as it thinks fit'; rules procedural, not exhaustive.

court_reasoning.text: Department could support AAC order on any grounds u/r 27; subject-matter was written down value; power to remand exists.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules 12, 28 not strictly applicable but s.33(4) sufficient.

court_reasoning.text: Agrees with High Court/Tribunal on first referred question in favour of assessee.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'All depreciation actually allowed' only for taxable income computation.

holdings.text: Tribunal had jurisdiction to entertain para 2 contention and remand to ITO.

statutes_cited.name: Income Tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs assessment, depreciation, written down value, appeals, references

statutes_cited.name: Taxation Laws (Part B States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Depreciation allowed under Part B State laws/rules relating to income-tax/super-tax/profits tax to be taken into account for written down value u/s 10(5)(b)

statutes_cited.name: Appellate Tribunal Rules, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedural rules on grounds in appeal, respondent support, remand

outcome.summary: Civil Appeals Nos. 411 to 413 of 1965 by assessee dismissed; Tribunal had jurisdiction to consider para 2 of Taxation Laws Order and remand matter to ITO.

key_quotes.text: The powers of the Tribunal in dealing with appeals are expressed in s.33(4) of the Act in the widest possible terms.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Rules 12 and 28 are not exhaustive of the powers of the Appellate Tribunal. The rules are merely procedural in character.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms s.33(4) not limited by rules
